titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: My Son had left a Letter signed by Mr. Nathaniel Curtis and himself as Executors and Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston, to the Selectmen of Princeton, proposing an amicable chancery suit in the Supreme Court of the State, to ascertain the right of the town, and the duty of the Executors, concerning a bequest, which was to take effect after the decease of Mrs. Alicia Boylston— I signed the Letter and it was sent this morning. Also an answer to my wife’s Letter of last Saturday from Baltimore. This morning before breakfast I brought up my diary, and then gave the day to visitation of my friends— I gave my Granddaughter Louisa-Catherine, the breast pin I had purchased for her yesterday— I called on Mitchell the engraver with the signet ring I purchased for her yesterday, and gave an order to engrave the Lion crest and the initial A. on the Cornelian stone— At Dr. George Parkman’s former residence I found he had removed to N. 1. Joy place, Belknap Street— I visited at the houses of H. G. Otis, Edward Brooks, Robert C. Winthrop and John Davis, and found no one of them at home. I had found Joseph Hall, 83 years old verging upon the very last stage of life, with his Sister not so old but as decayed, a melancholy contemplation of human life; but still he received me with a warm welcome. I was going to Dr. Frothingham’s when I met his wife in the Street who told me he was at New-York, and she expect him to return to-morrow. at Mr James H. Foster’s I saw his wife and daughter Elizabeth— I had met their daughters Mary and Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s door— I met also President Quincy in the Street, and first mentioned to him the idea of having short Memoirs of the Lives of the persons, whose Portraits are at the historical Society, with an engraving of one of the Portraits published in every future volume of the Society— I was ten minutes at my Son’s office where I saw Mr. A. C. Spooner. Found Mr Abbott Lawrence at home, and spent half an hour with him and Mrs and Miss Lawrence. Dined at Charles’s. Louisa C. Smith also dined there. After dinner I called at Dr. George Parkman’s, and passed an hour with him Mrs Parkman and their Son— About 7 this Evening my Son returned home from his political excursion to Ashburnham, Ashby, and Winchenden. I received in the course of the evening successively five columns from the Atlas office, from 7. to 11. O’Clock after I was in bed, of proof of my address at Braintree— There was still a column left, which I sent them word to publish without waiting for my revisal.

At half past 6 this morning My Son took his daughter Louisa Catherine to the Cars for Springfield.— She goes with Mrs Charles Sedgwick who resides and keeps a boarding school at Lenox, of only 8 girls— Louisa is to remain there one year— Mr Chapman late Mayor of Boston called to see me, and for an answer to an invitation which I had received to visit Medway and address the whigs there next Thursday or Friday. I declined having already taken cold and made myself so hoarse that it is doubtful whether I shall be able to speak next Wednesday at North-Bridgwater— I received also a Letter from Mr Bryant of that place enquiring by which road, I propose to go there, as some of the Citizens, wish to come out and meet me— This too I declined and answered Mr Bryant’s Letter, intimating a doubt whether, the state of my health and particularly of my voice will permit me to go at the appointed time. I visited Mr Robert C. Winthrop, and had a long conversation with him respecting his relative George W. Erving, his base treatment of me, and my public notices of him— I told Mr Winthrop, that when before the close of the session of Congress he gave me Charles J. Ingersoll’s, View of the Texas question and I observed to him my astonishment at the disclosure of Erving’s conduct, never having in the course of forty years acquaintance given him the slightest cause of offence; but having even named him to Mr Monroe as a candidate for the mission to France, and Winthrop said he would communicate to Mr Erving what I said;— I did purposely intend to give Mr Erving time to offer any explanation or apology to me—which the occasion required to repair the wrong he had done me.— He has not done it. By the Letter to Winthrop, from which he read me lately an extract, he expresses his regret at having assailed me; admits that I had given him no cause for it, and says that Jackson had gone far beyond any thing that he had said to him would warrant. But he had offered neither excuse, apology nor explanation to me, and in handling him as I have been compelled to do I have acted with extreme reluctance. I assured Mr Winthrop also that my Son would countenance no design or attempt to place him in competition with him, and that he would have my best wishes for his continuance in his present station as long as it would be agreeable to him and for his promotion to any other office of higher dignity and importance. He expressed much gratification at these assurances; but said he had determined not to serve in Congress after this next election— My next call was at the Atlas Office, where Mr Hayden returned me the manuscript of my Address at Braintree. It is published at full length in the Atlas of this morning, five columns. Small type— By these two Addresses, to the young men’s whig club at Boston and to my Constituents of the 8th. Congressional District I have put myself upon trial by God, and my Country. May God be my judge. With Louisa C. Smith whom I took up at Mr Foster’s I came out this afternoon to Quincy.

The Steamer Hibernia arrived last Night about 11. O’Clock having left Liverpool the 19th. of last Month. I looked in vain for her therefore in crossing the hill going to and returning from meeting— Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2. Timothy 1.7. [“]For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind”— This Epistle was written from Rome it is said when Paul was brought before Nero the second time— It was certainly very shortly before his martyrdom.— It is evidently written under great distress—in prison, abandoned by almost all his associates, some of whom he names, particularly those from Asia, his tone of complaint is not boisterous, nor pusillanimous but moderate, calm, without invective, and firm, specially exhorting Timothy to stand firm in the discharge of his duties, reminding him that the cause for which he suffers, is the purpose and grace of God “given us in Christ Jesus before the world began, but now made manifest by the appearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and hath brought life and immortality through the gospel:”— This is the cause with regard to which he says God hath not given us the spirit of Fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind. Mr Lunt as is his usual practice analyzed the words of his text and contrasted the Spirit of Fear, with that of the three others named in the text—Power, Love and a sound mind. His description of Fear was almost as graphic as that of Collins in his Ode on the Passions; and he specially noticed the opposition in which it is placed by the Apostle to a sound mind— He observed that a sound mind never admitted Fear— That the passion always disordered the mind, and disabled it for the exercise of its regular functions.— The fear of God itself he said was so qualified by the Spirit of Love, that it lost its evil qualities; but that simple Fear, was of all human qualities that most selfish and base— The closing exhortation to the auditory, to banish the Spirit of Fear, and adhere to those of Power and Love, and a sound mind, was spirited and acceptable.— In the afternoon some what unexpectedly Mr Francis Cunningham a Classmate of my Son appeared in the pulpit and preached from Ecclesiasticus 33.15. [“]So look upon all the works of the most high: and there are two and two, one against another.” There is much wisdom in the Book of Jesus the son of Sirach, but it is not in good taste for a protestant divine to take a text from it for a Sermon; and the Sermon itself was not equal to Mr Lunt’s— Mr Cunningham was a very promising youth— His maturity proves a disappointment.

The weather confined me to the house—dull gloomy with occasional showers. Mr William P. Apthorp, a son of George W. Apthorp formerly of this town but long since deceased came to solicit a contribution for a teacher’s school near Quincy, in the State of Illinois, where he resides and is one of the teachers of the school— The fortunes of that Apthorp family, are impressively melancholy. from Charles Ward Apthorp once a princely merchant of New-York with 20 children, through James Apthorp a Tory, but not a refugee of the revolution with five daughters and two sons, one of whom was George W. the father of this young man.— There is deep tragical romance in the story of almost every member of this family— A brother of this young man, died recently a missionary in the Island of Ceylon— Mr Bennett is the keeper of the Inn at North Bridgwater where I have engaged to go the day after to-morrow to deliver a political address— He came to advise me as to the best road to take in going there, that is, by Braintree, West Randolph and a corner of Stoughton— The distance is 12 miles, and Mr Bennett said there were a number of young men of the town of North Bridgwater and of several adjoining towns, who propose to form a cavalcade, and come 5 or 6 miles and meet and escort me to his house— I told him I had remonstrated against this in a Letter to Mr Bryant last week— But he said they would come, and I promised to take the road to meet them— A young man named John Stocker Freeman came to ask for advice His father named Thomas Freeman, and his mother whose maiden name was Collins, came in 1820 from Leominster in the County of Hereford in England, leaving two infant daughters one of whom was named Mary-Ann—the name of the other he does not know— He was born in Boston in 1821. and in 1823. his mother died in childbed with a daughter who died also— His father about the same time went to see, and he has heard nothing from him for many years— He himself had been brought upon Charity, had been several years at sea, and is now a Journeyman boot and shoemaker at Quincy point.— He had written letters to his Sisters to ascertain whether they were to be found but had received no answer— He wanted advice— I advised him to write again to his Sister, and enclose the Letter to Mr Edward Everett requesting his aid to discover the Sister. He said he would.

As I came into my library this morning the rain pattering on the windows and the wind howling round the corner of the house announced a Northeastern gale which continued till the afternoon, and then subsided without entirely clearing up.— The young man came again with a Letter to his Sister Mary Ann Freeman, Leominster County of Hereford, England, and one enclosing it to Mr Edward Everett our Minister in England asking his assistance to discover the sister, who he said might perhaps be married, and a certificate of the British Vice Consul at Boston Edmund A Grattan, dated the 19th. day of last July that Mrs Mary S. Smith of Boston personally appeared before him, and in his presence on oath declared that John Stocker Freeman, who had signed his name at the foot of the certificate, was to her certain knowledge the son of Thomas and Mary-Anne Freeman of Leominster in the County Hereford England, and formerly resident of Boston where the said John Stocker Freeman was born on the 23d day of September 1821.— The Deponent was uncertain whether the said Thomas Freeman were still alive or not but farther stated that the said Mary Ann Freeman (otherwise Mary Ann Collins[)] his wife, died in Boston in the month of March A.D 1823. The Letters to the Sister and to Mr Everett are well written, and the signature of the young man to the certificate is in a good hand. I promised to enclose these papers to Mr Everett, and would recommend the enquiries to his special attention— This was the only interruption of this day but I received from Nashville, Tennessee a Newspaper, containing Andrew Jackson’s first Answer to my address to the young men of Boston.— He is in great fury, but totally abandons the charge of the Erwin Treaty— I had been all the morning commenting upon James K. Polk’s Letter declaring his opinion in favour of the immediate annexation of Texas in which he assails me directly by name— And the remainder of the day and evening till 11 at night I was absorbed in writing a reply to Jackson’s letter to Robert Armstrong— The paper was enclosed to me by Boyd M’Nairy— Jackson denies positively that he ever advised the acceptance of the Sabine for the western boundary. Whether he equivocates upon the word advised, or has totally forgotten his interviews with me of 2. and 3. February 1819. The memory of violent men, is always the slave of their passions.— Jackson pledges himself to answer my charge further as soon as he can procure the Erving Manuscripts from Washington—

div.dateline: Quincy Wednesday 6. November 1844. N. Bridgwater— Quincy.
div.p: I added this morning one page to my notice of Andrew Jackson’s first answer to my summons in the address to the young men of Boston. I sent Kirk with my compliments to Mr Lunt and invited him to go with me to North Bridgwater, which he accepted— I took him up at his house at 8 O’Clock and we rode through Braintree, West-Randolph, and a corner of Stoughton, to North Bridgwater—12 miles. At West Randolph about half way we were met by a cavalcade of about one hundred men, the leader of whom came up to the carriage, accosted me by name and announced that they were citizens of Norfolk, Bristol and Plymouth Counties who had come to escort me to the place of meeting; for which I returned to them my cordial thanks— They accordingly formed a line and preceded the Carriage to Bennet’s tavern at North Bridgwater— Here I found Mr Bryant the Chairman of the whig Committee who had invited me, with a great crowd of respectable-looking persons from all the neighbouring towns of whom the persons named in the margin were with Thomas French of Canton were nearly all whom I had before known. Many were introduced to me, among whom several Warriors of the Revolution with War worn and time worn faces and forms. At half past ten a procession was formed preceded by a band of martial music and we marched to the meeting house— Mr Seth Sprague junr. of Duxbury presided— They began with a hymn— The Revd. pastor of the Church made a prayer— Mr. Sprague read a written paper complimentary to me, and introduced me.— From a quarter past 11. to half past one. I read from the pulpit with my manuscripts on the Bible my address which was listened to with close attention and well received. Mr Phillips and Mr Sprague read for me Jackson’s Letter to Armstrong and other Newspaper extracts— There was sung another hymn—an afternoon meeting at half past two, at which Mr Phillips was to speak was announced, and we adjourned to a frugal and tempeate dinner at the Inn.— Immediately after which I returned to Quincy left Mr Lunt at his house, and reached home at half past 4. Evening visit from Dr. W. B. Duggan, who invited me to deliver a Lecture next week.

There was a hard frost last night, and ice as thick as window glass was made on the ditch between my house and Charles’s— I saw the Sun rise from the corner of his house, and at 10. O’Clock left home and came in to Boston, leaving Louisa C. Smith, who proposes to pass a day or two with Mrs T. B. Adams.— I came immediately to my Son’s house N. 57. Mount Vernon Street. He had just returned from a tour to Nantucket and New-Bedford, where he has delivered electioneering addresses.— I went to the office of the Boston Courier, and gave Mr Buckingham the manuscripts of my address delivered yesterday at North Bridgwater—with the newspapers containing the Letters of James K. Polk and Andrew Jackson, and his charge about the Erwin Treaty— Buckingham proposes to publish the address on Saturday morning, and promised to send me proof columns of the paper to-morrow afternoon— I called at my Son’s office, and learnt that there is a second Letter from Andrew Jackson in answer to my address to the young men of Boston. This last is addressed to Blair the Editor of the Globe, and calls upon him for help in this controversy— There was great agitation in the streets, especially in State Street on the opposite sides of which are the Atlas and Times Newspaper Offices; before the doors of which crowds were collected awaiting the election returns from New-York— They were then highly favorable to the whig party— Dr. George Parkman called on me at my Son’s house— At 4. O’Clock we went and dined at Mr Samuel T. Armstrong’s, with the company named in the margin, excepting Mr Gorham Brooks, whom we found with Mrs. Charles on our return from the dinner— There was a very numerous democratic torch light procession this evening, who visited the dwelling house of Mr George Bancroft, the Democratic Candidate for the Office of Governor of the Commonwealth.— They were noisy but not otherwise disorderly— Soon after ten I retired to bed, and about midnight was awaked by the firing of 26. guns—the Io Triumphe of the democrats, on receiving the election returns from Albany.

I understood the meaning of the guns fired last night, on receipt of the election returns, from the western Counties of New-York, by the train of Cars from Albany. They settle the Presidential election, and James K. Polk of Tennessee is to be President of the United States for four years from the 4th of March 1845— What the further events of this issue may be—but it will be the signal for my retirement from public life— It is the victory of the Slavery element in the Constitution of the United States. Providence I trust intends it for wise purposes and will direct it to good ends— From the sphere of public action, I must at all events very soon be removed.— My removal now is but a few days in advance of the doom of Nature, and gives me time if I have energy to improve it, which will not be lost. I called this morning on Doctor Frothingham;—and just before reaching his door, met Mrs Isaac P. Davis who accosted me with grievous lamentation over the lost hopes of the election.— With Dr. Frothingham I examined and we construed the whole 16th. Elegy, of the second book of Properties—and we found that there is extant in English a translation in verse of this author, published in 1782. without the name of the translator— I called on judge Davis who condoled with me on the loss of the Presidential election; and also that in the list of stars in Rees’s Encyclopaedia Canopus is omitted— The judge thinks also that in Professor Williams’s account of their expedition to Penobscot to observe the transitthe star which they saw, and which he calls lucida Lyrae was in truth Arcturus— Immediately after dinner at 1/2 past 3. my Son left us to go by the railway cars to Haverhill to address a convocation of whigs there this Evening. I called at Libbey the jeweller’s shop with tufts of hair of Charles and his wife to be wrought into the signet Seal that I have procured for my wife. Mrs Gorham Brooks and Miss Henshaw visited Mrs Charles this afternoon; and Mr Brimmer the Mayor visited me this Evening. As I was passing by Dr. George Parkman came out from his house and walked with me home— Mr Tileston brought me proof Columns from the Courier Office of my North Bridgwater Address, and I passed the Evening with Mrs Charles in correcting it— There was another Cannonade this Evening for the Polk victory in New-York— Whig meeting this Evening at Faneuil Hall—and Daniel Webster’s Native American Speech.

My Son returned this morning from Haverhill just after we had breakfasted. He attended a numerous whig meeting there last Evening and made a speech. He comes home much gratified that this is the last of the electioneering campaign. There was also an immense meeting of whigs last evening at Faneuil Hall in Boston Daniel Webster was there, and made a speech commencing with What though the field be lost! All is not lost &c— The depression and despondency of the whig party at the issue of the presidential election in the State of New-York is beyond all example or precedent.— A young man by the name of Wheeler from Rutland in the County of Worcester, came this morning to see me. Merely to gratify his curiosity— We conversed about half an hour, upon indifferent topics—but no politics— I recovered the arrears of my journals, and answered an invitation to dinner from Mr David Sears for next Thursday. Accepted. But I can have no tranquility in the city in the daytime. My address at North-Bridgwater was published in the Boston Courier of this morning. On examining it, I found a considerable number of errors of the press.— I read it over, and corrected as many of them as I perceived without finishing I went out—called at Libby the jeweller’s shop, and took the signet ring which I have procured for my wife, under the seal of which is intertwined the hair of my son and his wife. The seal is the lion crest bearing the cross and under it the initial A. Thence I went to the Office of the Courier; where I finished the revisal of my address, and bespoke fifty copies of it which were sent to me at my Son’s house— After dinner at 4. O’Clock, Benjamin came for me with the Carriage— Charles’s wife and Mrs Frothingham took a short ride of a quarter of an hour, and then I came out alone to Quincy, reached my house just at the dusk of evening— I sent the Carriage for Louisa C Smith at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where she has been on a visit, since I left her here Thursday Morning. She returned in about half an hour; and I spent the Evening in folding up copies of my two addresses to my Constituents at Braintree and at North-Bridgwater, and in reflecting upon the duty that will now devolve upon me, to retire for the short remainder of my days from public life altogether— There are still duties enough to occupy the rest of my time, and to prepare me for my closing scene.

The Sun rose perfectly clear near the belfry of the Stone temple, by observation in November 1842. I found he rose directly behind the belfry on the 21st.— I shall be gone this year before that day— Mr Lunt preached this morning from 1. Corinthians 6:20— “Glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are Gods.” The Chapter from which this text is a clause of the last verse begins with a very severe reproof of the Christians at Corinth for going to Law with one another, not before the Saints their fellow Christians— The apostle declares that the saints shall judge the world—and this principle assumed thus early, and perseveringly pursued was doubtless the cause of the absolute power exercised during so many centuries by the Pope as the head of the Christian church This peremptory injunction never to go to Law with one another before infidel judges, was an unhinging engine which disabled to the extent of its influence all the roman tribunals of their power over the Christian sectarians. The Apostle then proceeds to declare that no person addicted to vicious morals, of person, property or good name shall inherit the kingdom of God. He then passes to a special, solemn, and deeply impressive charge against the sin of fornication, reminding them that other sins are offensive externally to the sinner himself but that this is a sin against his own body— He says they are bought with a price— That each one of them is the Temple of the holy ghost within him; not his own, but the property of God himself— Therefore says he glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God’s— This is a doctrine of angelic purity— On returning from meeting I found Mr Degrand at my house who dined and spent the day and evening with us till 9. O’Clock He brought out sundry newspapers, all confirming the fact of the total loss of the Presidential election— Mr Lunts afternoon sermon was from Mark 14.8. “She hath done what she could.” a Melancholy allusion to the condition of the present times, and to the disastrous issue of the Presidential Election— For the first time he alluded to the dismal prospects before us to the cause of human liberty, and the rights of petition and of protection— And he exhorted all his hearers to enquire of themselves whether they have done what they could for their salvation and preservation— Mr E. Price Greenleaf promised to call and visit my nursery with me to-morrow, and Mr Beale came and joined in lamentations with us at the Catastrophe which has befallen us.

Thick fog in the morning. Thunder and Lightening with a sprinkling of rain in the afternoon— Evening calm, moderate damp cloudy— It was the day of election for Electors of President, and Vice President of the United States— For Governor, Lieutenant-Governor Senators and Representatives of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and for members of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 29th. Congress.— For this last office I was the candidate nominated by the whigs, with two opponent nominationsWright of Roxbury by the Democrats, and Appleton Howe of Weymouth by the Liberty Party. I passed the day under a scarcely doubting anticipation of the failure of my own election— Mr Spear is the author of a Treatise against Capital Punishment, of which he brought me a copy for sale, which I took. He told me he was a Clergyman in Boston, but his name is not in the Register of the present year.— Mr Ellis and Mr Durfee were here after dinner Mr Ellis to speak about the claims of William Barron and Amasa Dunbar at Washington, and Mr Durfee, with a large Quarto Volume of Autograph signatures to which he desired the addition of mine with some lines.— He wished also some separate signatures on a sheet of blank paper and I gave him one, and several upon cards.— Mr Ball is a surgeon dentist, a young man, and he came with a large quarto Volume, for autographs—blank; and he wanted to begin the book with mine. Just before noon I went to the Stone Bank and settled my balance there, and then to the town house where I tore off my own name from the whig ticket and deposited the remainder of the ticket in the ballot box. I gave my own name which I had torn off to Harvey Field at his request— In the Evening E. Price Greenleaf came in with report of the election returns from the adjoining towns of Braintree, Randolph and Hingham—more favourable on the whole than I had expected; yet not enough so, wholly to resolve my doubts I wrote in the evening a Letter to Edward Everett to enclose those of J. S Freeman, and One to Erastus C. Benedict Secretary of the New-York Historical Society, accepting their invitation to attend their 40th. anniversary meeting on the 20th. I wasted no small portion of this day in searching for Andrew Jackson’s answers to my invitations to him to dine with me in January and March 1819. and found two of them. He denies having had any communication with me in 1819.

The following is the copy of the whig ticket voted for yesterday at Quincy, and for which I voted after tearing from it my own name, and pinning to the remnant of the paper the strip bearing the name of Samuel Curtis.

list.item: For Representative in Congress from District. N. 8.

div.p: The practice is for each voter to put into the ballot box the whole printed ticket, but every individual strikes out or effaces any name for which he chooses not to vote, and substitutes another name in its place— Candidates usually strike out their own names, but not always. There is no law, authorising the rejection of any man’s vote for himself.— The majority in the town of Quincy at the autumnal elections has been for several years democratic, consisting of transient Stone-cutters from New Hampshire— There were taken yesterday 719 votes. the number of registered voters in the town being 7Of the returns I only know that there were 345 for me, not a majority of the whole The Boston Atlas and Courier of this morning did not come by the regular mail, but I received a Courier under a blank cover— My Son came out from Boston with the Atlas, which has the returns from the whole Commonwealth except six towns— The whig ticket has been sweepingly successful.— The vote in the 8th Congressional District is 8041 for me 5322 for Wright 850 for Howe and all others. A result which I dared not expect and upon which I dare not attempt to express my feelings— Mr Lunt called on me to take leave on my proposed departure for Washington— I had no time to pack my trunks or assort my papers; but this afternoon at 4 O’Clock I left Quincy with my Son and Louisa C. Smith, who alighted at Mr James H. Foster’s, and I came to pass three days with my sons family at Boston.

Confined to the house all the morning by the rain, but without any thing more than the journal of yesterday and making up a file of Letters received within the last three weeks, and which I have not found time to answer, to file, and scarcely to read.— I have now four or five days of leisure—not sufficient to answer a tythe of the Letters which I ought to answer if I could. I did not finish the filing and endorsing of them— Mrs John Angier of Medford was here, and I agreed to go and pass the Evening at her house next Friday— At noon I called on Doctor N. L. Frothingham, and passed an hour with him examining his Propertius— Burman’s Edition— The best extant— My edition, Baskerville’s quarto has nothing but the text, and the passage quoted in in G. W. Erving’s Letter, is in the 20th. elegy of the second book—in Burman’s edition it is the 16th. But we found no explanation of the difference— The Doctor asked me what had so much excited the attention of my mind to this passage of Propertius? I told him it was the quotation of it in G. W. Erving’s Letter, and its whimsical connection of it with the Texas question, and with Erving’s base and treacherous treatment of me I called at Mr James H. Fosters and saw Mrs Foster, her daughter Mary and Louisa C. Smith— I told Miss Smith that I had promised to go to Medford on Friday, and must therefore postpone our return to Quincy till Saturday At the Boston Courier Office I asked the return of the three newspapers with marked passages cited and inserted in my Address at North-Bridgwater— They sent them to me this afternoon— I found myself after dinner, drowsy and went out again, purchased small toys for Charles’s four sons, and called at judge John Davis’s— He asked me to go with him this Evening to the Wednesday evening club of which I was a member in 1790. and again in 1802 and until 1809. It was this Evening at Dr Francis Parkman’s and I promised to go.— Returning home, I directed BenjaminAndrews to go at a quarter before eight with the Carriage and take up judge Davis in Milton place and come for me to Charles’s house which he did, and I spent the Evening with the Club at the Revd. Dr Francis Parkman’s— There were about 30 persons present—among whom five or six Strangers— At half past ten I took judge Davis home, and then returned to my Sons house. I found judge Davis exceedingly gratified with my notice of the founders of the Plymouth Colony in my Address at North-Bridgwater.

I forgot to mention that yesterday Morning I visited Mr and Mrs Francis P. Stockton, at their lodgings in Summer Street—Mrs Le kain’s. He was not at home but Mrs Stockton received me— This morning, I went astray in the library and stumbled upon a Museum Criticum or Cambridge Classical Researches in two 8vo. volumes 1826. and in the second volume at page 140. I find a review of two Articles; publications at Milan by Angel May of fragments of 6. Orations of Cicero—inedited found on Bobian palimpsest manuscripts—one passage from which I copy here as truly Ciceronian. Pro Scauro p. 11. [“]Venio nunc ad testes in quibus docebo non modo nullam fidem et auctoritatem, sed ne specium quidem esse aut imaginem— Testium etenim fidem primum ipsa tollit consensio, quae lata facta est compromisso Sardorum et conjuratione cogitata. Deinde illa cupiditas quae suscepta est spe et promissione praemiorum. Postremo ipsa natio, cujus tanta vanitas est ut libertatem a servitute nulla re alia, nisi mentiendi licentia distinguendum putet”— This definition of liberty is by no means confined to the antient Sardians— I walked out at noon, purchased at Libby’s a signet ring, and took it to Mitchell to be engraved— He promised it for Monday morning. Call at Charles’s office and then at the Morning Chronicle Office where I saw Mr Joshua Leavitt and the Ex-Texian S. P. Andrews— I asked for my manuscript copy of the record in the circuit Court U.S. of the Antelope case. He said that Mr Torrey’s counsel at Baltimore Reverdy Johnson had it— Call at J. P. Putnam’s Office 19. Court Street— I had received a Letter from him with an application from the young men’s institute at Hartford Connt. for another address from me. I requested him to inform them of my regret that it would not be in my power—which he promised to do. I dined with Charles at Mr David Sears’s with the company named between two lines in the margin— Very pleasant Mrs Sears asked me if I remembered her father, (Jonathan Mason) as a student in my father’s Office in 1774.— I did— On our return home this evening we found Dr and Mrs Frothingham here, and Mr Degrand— Mrs Edward Brooks, and Miss Henshaw had been here before. John Kirke was here with the trees for Mr Angier— I sent W B. Reed copies of my 3. speeches.

Morning visits from Harrison Gray Otis, and George Alexander Otis, men between whom there is no community, but of name; with the former of whom I have been in relations of personal intimacy and political controversy little short of three score years— For many years he acted a conspicuous part on the theatre of public affairs, and led in an unfortunate career of policy our native Commonwealth of Massachusetts— The result was to arrest him in his career of ambition, and he never reached beyond the Station of Senator of the United States, which he voluntarily relinquished, to move in the more contracted sphere of Mayor of the City of Boston; from which he also after short experience retired to affluent retirement in private life. He is abundantly wealthy, and has raised a numerous family, only one of whom has ever ventured on the stormy sea of politics, and meeting with adverse gales and some slight disaster, regained the shore and has not attempted a second voyage.— The father takes no longer any part in politics but lives, crippled with the gout, but otherwise in comfort, and the enjoyment of all that this world can afford, with two sons, one married daughter and several grand-daughter, awaiting in his 80th year his transition to Mount Auburn— My acquaintance with George Alexander commenced as a fellow passenger from London to New-York in 1817. Without an early classical education He has devoted his life to the literature of translation, which he has had the good fortune to make profitable. His translation of Botta’s history was eminently successful, and his Tusculan of Cicero have not proved a failure. He has unpublished translations of the other philosophical works of Cicero, and of the Offices—and also of Davila’s Civil Wars of France— He sat with me upwards of an hour—kind—courteous and incredibly flattering— Mrs Grinnell paid a morning visit to Mrs. Charles— I took to Dr Frothingham the volume of Ernesti’s Cicero, Boston Edition, containing the Dedication to Stiglitz— Call at Charles’s Office— Nobody there— At Cadmus’s 220. Washington Street— Letter of the 12th. from my wife at Washington— Answered immediately— I answered also two Letters from William Jackson of Newton. At 5. P.M. I rode with my Son 7 miles to Medford to the new house of Mr John Angier, where we spent the Evening, with a party of about 70. friends, family acquaintance and neighbours of Mr and Mrs Angier— His mother and Mrs T. B. Adams were there. His brothers Luther and Joseph—two Misses Osgood &c— We left the company at half past 9. and reached N. 57. Mount Vernon Street at a quarter past ten—

Met at my Son’s office Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and examined and signed 6th. and 7th. accounts of administration as Executors of the last Will and Trustees of the Estate of Ward Nicholas Boylston. The 6th. extending from the last settlement till the death of Mrs. Alicia Boylston, 8. October 1843 and the 7th from that date to the present. I called at the Office of the Boston Atlas, where Dr Brewer gave me copies of the paper of 9. October 1844. containing my address to the young men’s whig club at Boston on the 7th. The address of 30. October at Braintree is in the Atlas of 2. November, and the address of 6. November at North-Bridgwater, in the Boston Courier of 9. November. These 3 papers embrace my defence against the infamous conspiracy of Andrew Jackson, George W. Erving, Aaron Vail Brown, and Charles Jared Ingersoll. I have by design taken this mode of appealing to my Constituents, to the world and to posterity— My constituents have answered and nobly vindicated my character.— In the same District where in 1842 I received only 5votes I have now received 8091 and where I had then a majority of less than 500 I have now a majority exceeding 1900— The voice of the world and of posterity is yet to be heard.— After a short ride with Mrs Charles, I came out with my son his boys John Quincy, and Charles Francis, and Louisa C. Smith— After dinner Charles and his two sons returned to Boston— Mr Nathan Procter Smith, with his wife, three sons of about 12 10, and 7 and a daughter of 9 came to see me— That, he said was all his object— He only wished that all his children should see me— He lives in Roxbury—the new part of the town, Eustis Street and does business in Boston, in connection with the great Western Railway.— Of this Class of visitors I have many, but do not feel myself much flattered by their motives. “Dulce est digito monstrari et dicier hic est”—says Juvenal, but it is pleasing only to vanity— The curiosity to see a person of great notoriety imports nothing favourable or friendly to him— It is mere selfish curiosity— This Evening I answered a Letter of B. A. Gould and 7 others, a Committee of the Boston Latin School Association of 1. Septr. last asking for information which they supposed me to possess but which I did not—and I wrote to my wife to enclose three bills of lading of articles shipped for Washington in the Schooner Columbia and the brig Mozart.

From the S.E. corner of Charles’s house, the Sun rose one full disk North of the Temple belfry which performed a complete transit over the disk in 7 minutes. when the whole disk was behind the pillars of the belfry, the temple clock struck seven— True to the Sun to a minute— Last evening a Professor Church, a frenchman notwithstanding his name, accompanied by Dr Clark, an Episcopal Clergyman from Northampton, came with an introductory Letter from Revd Samuel K. Lothrop.— Professor Church is a teacher of the French language, upon a plan of his own,—and he wished me to examine his plan and give him a certificate of my opinion of it.— I told him that I made it a general rule, never to give certificates; and that if I did ever give one I had now no time for the examination— Dr Clark comes out to perform divine service to-morrow at the episcopal church where there is at present no Rector—Mr Robinson having been dismissed. This day Mr Lunt preached in the Temple from Luke 17.21. [“]For behold, the kingdom of God is within you.” This was the answer of Jesus to the Pharisees who enquired when the kingdom of God should come? It was immediately after the miracle of cleansing of ten lepers, only one of whom returned to glorify God; and he a Samaritan— In the verse immediately preceding the text Jesus says the Kingdom of God cometh not with observation— That is heralded with the sound of a trumpet. Mr Lunt said it was a Revolution in the human character— That it was the reign of righteousness and truth upon earth— Oh! how far yet from its consummation— Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from Philippians 4.5— “Let your moderation be known unto all men.”— He expatiated well upon the importance of this precept, as a lesson of Prudence.— It is not only moderation, but notorious universally known moderation— And yet how much more emphatic and solemn is the injunction, with the additional clause of the text, which Mr Lunt omitted—“The Lord is at hand” That your moderation should be known, is for your own benefit—propitiates the good will of others, and disarms enmity and malice— But the consideration that the Lord is at hand, reminds us our responsibility to God. It is the pure dictate of duty; and whether known to man or not cannot escape the notice of the Lord who is at hand— After Meeting I called and took leave of Mrs T. B. Adams and Elizabeth. Mrs Stebbins and John Foster— Visit from Mr and Mrs Cushing of Dorchester.

Occupied from the moment of rising till 11. A.M. in packing up for my journey to Washington, and then Benjamin F. Andrews brought me with Louisa C. Smith into Boston. John Kirk brought in our trunks in a waggon— I left Miss Smith at Mr James H. Foster’s door—called at Mitchell, the engravers and at Libby the Jeweller’s for the signet ring which I had bespoken and which was at last sent to me by Mr Libby, and received while we were at dinner.— I gave my English Signet ring with the cock and the motto “Watch” to my Son Charles’s wife— At his Office I endorsed my name in blank on the certificate for 30 shares, 3000 dollars of the Western Railroad Stock; and took with me to be executed at Washington the Deed to the Boston and Plymouth Rail-road Corporation of the Lands which they have taken of mine in Quincy— At my Son’s house N. 57. Mount Vernon Street—Mr Brooks—his son Edward, Mrs Sidney Brooks, Dr Frothingham, and John G. Palfrey Esquire the Secretary of the Commonwealth dined, and I took leave of them—and afterward of P. P. F. Degrand, who called in the course of the Evening— We had a pleasant dinner party, enlivened with literary conversation. I received an invitation to an Evening party next Friday from Mrs Francis Bacon a sister of Mrs Sidney Brooks; a Lady with whom I have no personal acquaintance— Of course my absence will make my acceptance of the invitation impossible. Before leaving Quincy this morning I planted in the garden, and in one flower pot a basket full of apples, pears, apple-seeds, peach and plum-stones, English-white Oak acorns, and shag bark walnuts from the old garden Summer house tree, which I have been gathering all the Summer and Autumn with the intention of planting them at leisure but no leisure have I had. From the same cause I leave my books and papers in confusion worse confounded— No part of my life has been more totally absorbed by toil than the four months and six days since I last returned from Washington I sent a message to Dr Duggan to inform him that I should not be able to deliver a Lecture at the Quincy and Milton Lyceum, and despatched the Letter to William Jackson, postponing the Address at Newton till next Spring

I rose in time to finish my journal of yesterday, and to breakfast before half past seven O’Clock— Then took a hack to the depot of the Worcester Railroad, and took passage in the day line by the Long-Island-rail-road to New-York— My Son accompanied me to the Car, and took leave of me in it— As did also Mr James Savage— I found there Dr Codman, Mr Young and Mr Ellis, delegates, my associates from the Massachusetts historical Society to attend the anniversary celebration of the New-York historical Society, to-morrow. We started precisely at 5 minutes past 8 as I supposed for Providence; but it had been the coldest night of the Season, and all the windows of the car were closed, and dew obscured— At 10. O’Clock the Car stop’d and I was surprized to hear we were at Worcester— The stoppage was scarcely for five minutes—and we proceeded in the same cars to Norwich where we crossed over the bridge of the Quinepaug swelling into the Thames; a stupendous work—we followed the Southern bank of the river seven miles down, where the Steamer New-Haven was in waiting to receive us— We noticed as we passed along the region of the Pequod War, and the reserve upon which the remnant of the Mohegan tribe yet dwell 3000 acres, and about 70 Souls.— We passed down the river, stopping at New-London only time enough to take in passengers, and in two hours and a quarter, with a bright Sun a smooth Sea and a chilling Northwester; landed at Greenport a small village on Long-Island— Here we took again the cars, at 3. O’Clock having dined in the boat and at 7 in the Evening alighted at Brooklyn—95 miles in 4 hours— We immediately crossed the ferry, took a hack and at half past 7. found ourselves (Mr Young, with a young Lady Miss Toppan of New-Hampshire, Mr Ellis and myself[)] at Bunker’s hotel or boarding house in Broadway.— Exactly 12 hours from my Son’s house in Boston— Dr Codman stop’d at Brooklyn— On the road I had much conversation with sundry Strangers, but chiefly with Mr Ellis, Minister of a Congregational church and Society in Charlestown, and a writer of sundry Articles in Sparks’s American biography— He is intimately acquainted with the history of the Pequod War, of which he mentioned to me many incidents, and is also much interested in the controversies in which Mrs Hutcheson so largely figured.
20. IV— VI. Wednesday— Rain— Dark Clouds and November gloom.

The visitors were so numerous and the transactions of the day so various, that they left scarcely a distinct impression upon my mind of any thing— Professor Mason as chairman of the Committee of arrangements of the New-York historical Society came early and informed me of the arrangements for the day. A Committee of 5 members of the Society with Mr. W. Beach Lawrence, a Vice-President, came welcomed me to the city— An interlude of no small note was the friendly visit of Coll. Bankhead to apprize me that Mr Samuel L. Governeur, was in possession of a Letter from General Jackson, fully approving the Florida Treaty— We dined at Bunker’s at half-past 3. and at half past four Carriages from the Society came and took me with Dr John Codman, Revd. Alexander Young and Revd. George E. Ellis to the Astor-House, where we took up Mr Leverett Saltonstall, and proceeded to the Library room of the University where the Meeting of the historical Society was held, the President Albert Gallatin being in the Chair. The numbers of the Society are unlimited, and the only business done, was the admission by an open vote sundry members, nominated at a previous meeting; and the nomination of sundry others among whom was John Jacob Astor.— The assembly was quite numerous and thronged the spacious apartment.— They then joined in a procession of Carriages to the Church of the Messiah, of which Orville Dewey is the Pastor, where an Oration was delivered by John Romeyn Brodhead upon historical subject— He has been an agent of the State to collect documents relating to its history in England, France and Holland—of which agency he gave an interesting account; interspersed with several passages of beautiful eloquence— The house is large, and was well filled— The Discourse was preceded by a prayer by Revd Dr. De Witt of the reformed Dutch Church. The closing benediction was by Dr Codman.— From the Church between 8 and 9. O’Clock the Society adjourned to the New-York Hotel where a magnificent dinner was prepared for 300 persons— Mr Gallatin had not gone to the Church; but presided at the table for about an hour, and then retired before the speeches began. Mr William Beach Lawrence presided the remainder of the Evening.— Mr Luther Bradish late Lieutt. Governor of New-York toasted me, or roasted me with a speech so fulsome that it overset all my philosophy, and I stammered a reply the only palliation of which was its brevity— The speeches followed till sometime passed midnight when I retired with my colleagues Saltonstall, Young and Ellis. Mr Samuel L. Gouverneur promised to call on me to-morrow Morning at 8 O’Clock—

Alexander S. Johnson, Grandson of my long since departed brother Charles, was one of my visitors yesterday, and told me of the disastrous accidents which befell his father and his brother William about three weeks since—the father having been thrown out of a Chaise in which he was riding with his wife, and broken one arm, and sprained a wrist— And William having been overset in a Carryall, and sprained his ancle so as for some time to walk with a crutch— Last Evening Dr Wainwright who sat next to me at table, asked me if I was aware that Mr Gouverneur possessed a Letter from General Jackson to President Monroe fully approving the Florida Treaty in 1819— I said I was— He asked me, if I had received the information from or through John A. Hamilton. I said I had not, but was not at liberty to tell him from whom I had received it. He said the reason of his asking me the last question was that there had been some days since a conversation upon the subject in the Office of Mr Hamilton. About 11. O’Clock while at table I received a Letter fromBlakeman M.D. enclosing an old Massachusetts Pine-tree shilling, which he wished through me to present to the New-York historical Society— Dr. Blakeman was to me a total Stranger, but after consultation with Mr Lawrence, and Dr. Wainwright I presented the shilling and gave a brief summary history of the coinage of 1652. and I took the occasion to pay a tribute of respect to Albert Gallatin, which I had forgotten to do when up before.— This morning Mr Gouverneur called on me at 8. And told me that he had according to his recollection a Letter from General Jackson to President Monroe, written at New-York in February 1819. and speaking of the Florida Treaty—as universally approved. A confidential Letter from W. L. L. Brent to Mr Monroe intreating him to place no confidence and trust nothing to George W. Erving and a Letter from Thomas Jefferson to Mr Monroe speaking lightly of the French claim West of the Mississippi— He promised to communicate these papers to me on this return to Washington— At 9. O’Clock I crossed the river to Jersey city and took the train of Cars for Philadelphia— Mr Young and Mr Ellis came down and took leave of me at the ferry— Mr Blunt crossed the ferry and took leave of me at the Cars. Among my fellow travellers were Coll Talcott and Professor Bartlett of West Point— We reached Philadelphia at 5 P.M and took lodgings at Jones’s Union Hotel in Chesnut Street—

div.p: Among the Passengers whom I met yesterday at the passage of the ferry boat from New-York to Jersey city formerly Paulus Hook, wasCogswell who was one of the Students at Harvard University in 1806. when I was installed Professor of Rhetorick and Oratory at that institution— He was one of the Committee of Students who requested a copy for publication of my inaugural address— I believe their chairman, . . . had then the reputation of being the first scholar at the University— He was then about 20.— He is now, within two or three years of 60— I should not have recognized him, but Mr Blunt introduced him to me; and he remembered the delivery of my Lectures— His career has been respectable, but not so highly distinguished or successful, as might have been expected. He told me he was now employed by Mr John Jacob Astor as an Agent for carrying into execution his donation of four hundred thousand dollars to the City of New-York, for a library— Our arrival at Philadelphia last evening was delayed by an accident which befell the corresponding train of Cars going from Philadelphia to New-York— Between Princeton and Trenton their locomotive engine ran off the track and stuck in the mud— Their train barred the passage to ours, and we were obliged to change our seats and take others in the train from Philadelphia, to which the accident had happened— The train which we left was taken by the passengers from Philadelphia for whom another engine was procured, and baggage enough to load a ship was mutually transferred. The detention was of about two hours and a half; and professor Bartlett more than once reminded me of the melancholy disaster which befell the train of Cars, between Amboy and Bordentown in November 1833. when he and his wife and two infant daughters were fellow passengers.— He said his wife and daughters who were much injured by the accident had all entirely recovered from its effects— This morning Coll. and Mrs Talcott, and professor Bartlett proceeded on their journey and Mr Huntington was the only acquaintance left me in the house— Ebenezer Tucker of New-Jersey heretofore a member of Congress now 87 years of age, visited me in the course of the day, and Mr Meredith of Baltimore dined with us at the Lady’s Ordinary— I received of George Rundle, York Street 61. dollars a final dividend of the Schuylkill permanent bridge stock, and at the Bank of North-America Chesnut Street an order on the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington for 240 dollars for 8. Coupons of interest on Cincinnati bonds— In the evening I went to the Chesnut Street Theatre and saw the Hunchback, and the President incog.

Rain all Night— I rose to a minute in time to finish the record of yesterday, to breakfast and walk to the depot in Market street of the Railroad Cars for Baltimore. At 8 O’Clock they started; and at a quarter before 3. landed me in Pratt-street, Baltimore. As the Sun rose the rain held up; and the sky was all the morning clearing off— By the time we reached Baltimore it was throughout the hemisphere crystal clear and so continued for the remnant of the day. I left Benjamin F. Andrews, my help, with his spaniel dog at the depot to get his dinner at the United States Hotel, and to take care of the baggage, and walked to Barnum’s for a dinner— Missed my way, and strolled, till I met Lloyd N. Rogers, the first person whom I knew, after leaving Jones’s Union Hotel in Philadelphia.— He walked with me, bewailing all the way the issue of the election and left me at Barnum’s door.— At the Lady’s Ordinary they were at table, and there I met Commodore Ballard and Mrs Ballard, with a little girl 8 or 9. years old their granddaughter— The Commodore welcomed me with great cordiality; told me that it was a constant satisfaction to him that I had signed his commission, and remembered as I did, that in May 1836, he had given up at 11. O’Clock at Night his own chamber at Barnum’s, to me for a lodging, when there was not another in the house to be had.— He then took for the Night a bed in the chamber of Commodore Alexander J. Dallas then a fellow lodger here, but recently deceased as commander of the squadron in the pacific. After dinner, I returned to the depot and took a seat in the train of Cars for Washington, which started at 5. O’Clock for Washington City. at the relay house 8. Miles from Baltimore, the termination of the Cumberland railroad, Mr John J. Crittenden a Senator of the United States from Kentucky, and Mrs Crittenden, and W. C. M’Causlen a member of the House from Ohio came into the Car, and arrived with us at Washington soon after 7. by the light of the moon, almost rivaling the noonday. From the depot at the foot of the Capitol hill I walked home, and had scarcely entered the house, when Dr Thomas followed me— Mrs John Adams was confined to her bed, and my dear wife, though not in bed is afflicted with one of those stubborn nervous coughs which seem to deny respite or relief.— And thus on reaching home, I am called to mingle with the notes of gratitude for continued blessings the supplication for further mercies— Mr Cutts and his daughter came in soon after and spent an hour of the Evening here— And after the visitors were gone, I mused over the prospects before me; with the impression that they portend trials more severe than I yet have passed through—and with a reliance alone on him who rules above.

My wife was quite ill great part of this day, but promisingly better this Evening.— I gave her this morning the signet ring which I purchased for her in Boston, upon the Cornelian stone of which Mitchell engraved the crest of the Lion bearing the cross, and under it the Letter A. with the hair of our Son Charles and his wife in a box under the stone— And I gave to my granddaughter Mary Louisa the signet ring which I procured for her, and on which Mitchell engraved the cock, with the motto “Watch”— And for the significancy of the device, at my request she read to me the 13th. chapter of Mark—the last verse of which is—And what I say unto you, I say unto all, Watch. I attended public worship this morning at the second presbyterian church, where Mr Knox preached from Luke 19.41. “And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it.”— There was something deeply saddening in this discourse. Jesus wept over the city because he foresaw and foretold the destruction of it which was so soon afterwards to ensue. Mr Knox remarked that there but two occasions in the life of Jesus, upon which it is recorded that he wept— This, and at the death of Lazarus before he restored him to life— That these tears were indications of the purest benevolence, and the most exquisite tenderness; all which is apparent— But the destruction of Jerusalem has no observable connection with their treatment of Jesus Christ. Judea was conquered by the Romans as other Nations were, and in the process of that conquest Jerusalem was taken and the second temple was destroyed— In foretelling this event Jesus affirms that if Jerusalem had repented and believed in him, she would not have suffered that dreadful fate; but the Judean war of Vespasian and Titus had no earthly connection with the life and death of Jesus of Nazareth. Mr Knox in the application of his discourse, put it, as an awful question to his hearers whether this city was not as guilty, and as deserving of the afflictive judgment of Heaven as Jerusalem was in the days of Jesus Christ; but he did not specify the sins which may draw down destruction upon it— Slavery is the great besetting sin of this city; but of that Mr Knox took no note— He complained that of 25 or 26 thousand inhabitants, not more than 3000 attended upon any religious exercises of public worship, a fact that seems incredible but otherwise the sins of this city are not more aggravated than those of the age in other populous cities, and that the vices of the age, and the sins of this Nation deserve a severe judgment of Heaven is too painfully true to be denied— May that judgment be averted, and the manners of the age and nation be reformed and purified. After dinner I attended at St. John’s church where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity, and Mr Slaughter a Clergyman from Virginia preached from John 7.17. [“]If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself.”— Eclipse of the moon.

I arrived here on Saturday Evening with a clear sky, bright moonlight, and the atmosphere of May rather than of November— Yesterday Morning it was yet warm; but the wind came round to the North-west and it was all day growing cold; and as I was returning from church last evening, between 5 and 6. O’Clock, I saw the moon just risen with the shadow of the earth already encroaching upon her disk— The eclipse was total and lasted upwards of three hours but the cold was so pinching that I could look at it only once or twice; and then less than five minutes at a time— This day has been of bright clear disqualifying cold— I unpacked my trunks, and immediately missed one or two articles, precisely those I wanted and left behind— It made a day of fruitless search and of wasted time. I walked out for exercise, and at the National Intelligencer Office saw Mr Gales in deep distress at the issue totally unexpected issue of the Presidential election— He is in despair and foresees that it must prove his irretrievable ruin. It has been accomplished by fraud through the Slave representation.— The partial associations of native americans, Irish catholics, abolition Societies, Liberty party.— The Pope of Rome, the Democracy of the sword, and the dotage of a ruffian, are sealing the fate of this Nation, which nothing less than the interposition of omnipotence can save. I asked Mr Gales to send me the Intelligencer, from the 14th. which he did, and I sent him the Boston Atlas of 2. Novr. and the Courier of 9. November containing my addresses at Braintree and at North Bridgwater which he had no read— After I came home, Mr Michael Nourse a ruling elder of the second Presbyterian Church called on me and enquired if I would consent to go as a delegate from that Church and Society, to the Sabbath day Convention to be held at Baltimore next Wednesday. I said I should feel honoured by the election, but doubted whether it would be in my power to go. The meeting of the Society was held at half past four this afternoon— I did not attend it but in the Evening the Revd. Mr Knox, and Mr Nourse came as a Committee from the Meeting to inform me that I had been elected a delegate from the Society to the Convention. I expressed my grateful sensibility for the honour conferred upon me, and promised to attend the Convention, if it should be in my power. I know not if this acceptance be prudent, but as an act of kindness to the Society and a testimony of respect for the Sabbath I believed it proper.

I found myself unexpectedly absorbed in business unforeseen— Received a multitude of Letters among which one from my son at Boston enclosing a Letter to my wife from her Sister Mrs Harriet Boyd with six draugts by her upon me and my son, one for eighty dollars being her portion of the surplus of the Estate of Thomas B. Johnson ordered by the judge of the orphan’s Court last July to be distributed among the heirs. Another for 197 dollars 78 Cents due to Mrs Boyd on her annuity the interest on 5000 dollars, Mr Johnson’s bequest to her. Then three draughts each for 60 dollars by anticipation payable 14 January, April and July 1845. and one payable 14 October 1845—for 197:78. For all these Mrs P Boyd imploringly calls for 300 dollars immediately, to save her and her family from being turned out of house and home by the forfeiture of the Estate on which they live— I wrote to Charles to remit to George Boyd a post note of the merchants Bank Boston to be sent under cover to me, to be forwarded by me to him in two separate halves for 500 dollars—taking on myself the responsibility of the future payments as they shall become payable My wife insisted that 300 dollars of her first years annuity from her brothers bequest which Charles has invested for her should be pledged for the payment of the sums, advanced on Mrs Boyd’s draughts— I sent for two Justices of the Peace who came, Mr Clarke and Mr King who came and witnessed and took the acknowledgment of myself and my wife to the Deed of my lands in Quincy taken by the Boston and old Colony Rail-road, the consideration for which is left in blank to be filled up. I received also from John G. Palfrey Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, a Letter my credential as the representative of the 8th. Congressional District of Massachusetts in the 29th. Congress together with a list, of all the votes returned—upwards of 14000. I called at the National Intelligencer Office to ask for a paper of 28 September and to offer my whole file of duplicates; but neither Gales nor Seaton was there. At the Clerk’s Office of the House of Representatives but French was gone home to dinner. I found Mr Mehan in the library— My wife was so ill this Evening that I wrote to Revd. Mr Knox to excuse myself for not going to Baltimore to-morrow— But she was afterwards better and persuaded me to go.

At 5. I breakfasted, and rode to the depot of the train of Cars for Baltimore— Met there the Revd Dr Laurie, and Mr Knox whom I informed that my wife being better I had concluded to come to Baltimore, and attend the Sabbath day convention At 6. we started and at a quarter past 8. alighted at the depot in Baltimore— I walke to Barnum’s Hotel, and bespoke a bed chamber. Met there Mr Chambers of Chambersburg and Harmar Denny of Pittsburg and Mr Newkirk of Philadelphia, and sundry others delegates to the Convention— At a quarter before 10 Mr Knox called for me, and I went with him to the first Baptist Church in Sharp Street which we found filled with about 1200 delegates to the National Lord’s day Convention— Mr Hanmer the Minister of the Church moved that judge Willard Hall of Delaware should be chairman of the meeting to organize the Convention which was voted by acclamation and he took the Chair. Two Secretaries were chosen and a Committee of 5. Bishop Waugh, Dr Bond, Mr Stilman, Mr Atwood, and Mr Gideon, were appointed to submit officers and rules for the government of the Convention— While they were out, Mr Powell of Philadelphia was requested to address the meeting which notwithstanding some objections he did— The Committee soon came in and reported John Quincy Adams, President—seven Vice Presidents 1. Willard Hall, 2. Theodore Frelinghuysen 3. Dr Nott. 4 Bishop Waugh 5. J. A. Brown, 6. H. V. D. Johns 7. J. Kingsford—and four Secretaries, Harmar Denny C. W. Ridgely, C. A. Davis, and T. Stilman, which nominations were approved by an unanimous vote— I took the Chair and made a very brief address to the Convention; and the Committee on Officers and rules made a supplementary report of 8 rules— The first of which was that the Convention should meet at 9. A.M—sit till 1 p.m. adjourn till 3. P.M adjourn at 5. and meet again at 7. P.M.— There was some discussion whether the question should be taken upon all the rules at once, or upon each rule separately—after some debate a motion was made to take one question upon all the rules, which was carried by a large majority and they were adopted with only two or three dissenting votes— There was much discussion about a roll call of the members, and after an attempt
to read over the names which it was found would consume more time than the Convention could spare a committee of enrolment was appointed, to whom all members having credentials were authorised to present them and members having no credentials were to be accredited upon their own declaration— A Letter from T. Frelinghuysen was read regretting his inability to attend the convention, whereupon James Clarke was appointed 2d Vice President in his place— Bishop Waugh, Methodist read a Letter addressed to the Convention with enclosed papers, but a Committee had been appointed to report the business to be acted upon by the Convention; and a rule required that all communications addressed to the Convention should be referred to the business Committee— They reported seven Resolutions the first of which was a general one, avering the duty of all men to remember the Sabbath and keep it holy. This started a snarling debate Mr Lemmon, a delegate from Baltimore, and Mr Magruder of Virginia, who insisted that the Sabbath being an abrogated Jewish institution, in no wise binding upon Christians. This was in substance nothing more than an objection to the use of the word Sabbath, instead of the Lords day; but they misunderstood it as an infidel attempt to break up the Convention itself— Attempts were made to silence Mr Lemmon and Mr Magruder— They were repeatedly called to order; Magruder was loudly hissed, and there were numerous calls to turn him out. I maintained them both in their right to speak, until they were heard through— A motion was made to lay Mr Lemmon’s amendment on the table, and question made whether that motion was debatable. I decided that it was, there being no rule to the contrary— It was accordingly warmly debated till the time for adjournment, immediately before which the question was taken and Mr Lemmon’s amendment was laid on the table by an apparently unanimous vote. At 1. O’Clock the Convention adjourned till 3.— As we were retiring Mr Lemmon put into my hand a printed paper, headed, Report for the Lord’s day Convention— I had forgotten in packing up my valise, to put in it—a pen—which reminded me of La gageure imprévue. I stop’d at a shop, and purchased a paper of Camel steel pens.— At Barnum’s they had dinner at 1/2 past 2. I found myself seated by Lloyd N. Rogers, but was obliged to leave the table, dinner half over, to take the Chair of the Convention at 3.— The first and 7. other resolutions offered by the business Committee were now passed in quick succession by unanimous votes before Messrs. Lemmon and Magruder came in— The Convention adjourned from 5 to 7. and sat again from 7 to 10.— The house crowded to its utmost capacity. Adjourned to 9. to-morrow morning

I could not comprize in one page the journal of yesterday, nor finish the account of the day before breakfast— My wife had charged me to procure for her two handsome picture frames for the portraits of her eldest sister, Nancy, the first Mrs Hellen and of herself painted by Savage, before they were married— I went accordingly to the shop of Mr Fryer in Gay Street— My wife had named him to me, and the bar-keeper at Barnum’s had assured me that his shop was the best shop for that Article in the City— I found and bespoke the two frames for 20 dollars and directed them to be sent to the depot of the rail-road Cars, boxed up—this afternoon or to-morrow morning as I should thereafter advise— Precisely at 9. O’Clock I took the Chair of the Convention, of whom very few members were present Bishop Waugh of the methodist episcopal church made the prayer kneeling— The Revd. Justin Edwards Chairman of the business Committee presented successively a number of resolutions all having reference to the observance of the Lord’s day; and three several addresses to the Canal Commissioners to the Directors of Railroads, and to the People of the United States, all of which were read and adopted by the Convention without debate— Sundry members of the Convention offered separate Resolutions, which were referred to the business committee, then reported by them with such modifications as they thought advisable then read and adopted without opposition— In this way Resolutions recommending to innkeepers to close their barrooms on Sundays— To the officers of the army, exhorting them not to exact military service from the soldiers on that day, and a recommendation to the ministers of the gospel to preach a sermon once every year urging the faithful observanc of the day.— and there was a resolution expressing the regret of the Convention, that Congress should have within the last few years repeatedly have transacted public business on Sunday. As the essential business of the Convention was done, I resolved to return home this evening, and thinking it fair to leave judge Hall a turn to preside, I took leave of the Convention before adjourning at 1. O’Clock, upon which they passed a vote of thanks— I dined at Barnum’s—excused myself to J. P. Kennedy who had invited me to dine with him to-morrow, took the Cars for Washington at 5. found Benjamin at the depot, and walked home.

I called this morning at the Bank of the Metropolis—and deposited the order from the Bank of North America, for 240 dollars, which was entered to my credit as cash, and they gave me a new Bank-book, as I have mislaid my old one. Next at the Franklin Insurance Company Office I recived a dividend of 316.75 which I deposited in the Patriotic Bank— At the National Intelligencer Office I saw Mr Seaton, and returned two papers of the 18th. and 19th. of this month of which they had sent me duplicates but they had not a spare copy of the paper of 28 September last which is yet missing from my file— I brought up my journal but could write nothing else— From breakfast time till past noon upwards of three hours I was swallowed up in reading Newspapers, received this morning— The Baltimore Patriot of Yesterday, and Sun of this day contain detailed reports of the proceedings of the Lord’s day Convention till their final adjournment last evening— In the Boston Semi-weekly Advertiser of Wednesday the 27th. received under a cover endorsed George E. Ellis, there is a report of the proceedings at the 40th. anniversary of the New-York historical Society on the 20th. doubtless written by Mr Ellis himself, and in a spirit of kindness to me.— In the Brooklyn Evening Star of Tuesday the 26th. received under cover without indication from whom, there is a Letter dated at Quincy—Masstts. 23. November 1844. signed E. M. and giving an account of a visit to the grave yard at Quincy, and to the houses and chambers in which my father and myself were born— Of Mr Lunt’s 200th. anniversary discourses with my hour glass hymn— All these papers I read with a deep interest—was it egotism? vanity? pride? or excusable weakness If so, may it be forgiven!— I had a long visit from Mr Pakenham, the Minister from Great Britain— He said there had not been one line of correspondence between Mr Calhoun and him since the close of the last Session of Congress—nor to his knowledge between Mr Edward Everett and the British Government— He appears to apprehend no collision between the two Governments— Richard D. Cutts was here this afternoon, and Philip R. Fendall in the Evening— I gave him the newspaper copies of my three Addresses to the young men of Boston; to my constituents at Braintree and at North-Bridgwater. He is one of the very few men who will read them all.— A young man from Lowell by the name of Whittemore was here in great want.

There is a great variety of business, public and private which passes over from one session of Congress to the next, and of which I have found it extremely difficult and not unfrequently impossible to keep the thread. In the intervals between the Sessions individuals apply for pensions, for petitions to Congress or pension claims new or old before Congress or the Executive Departments— I have kept since 1835 a docket of petitions, which have absorbed a vast portion of my time, besides publishing lists of them in the National Intelligencer— A want of system in keeping a day-book of all business under my charge whether before Congress or the departments has often made me lose sight of particular cases, and had the appearance and the results of neglect. Instead of keeping one continuous book I have scattered my minutes and memoranda over numerous quires of paper, and know not where to look for the one, I happen at any time to want.— I found this morning on my files of papers, three applications for pensions, and two for Cadet warrants, which required my immediate attention. 1. The declaration of Mary Jennison of Boston, widow of William Jennison 2. The Declaration of Hannah Allen, heretofore widow of Zebah Thayer—now of Roxbury—and 3. A Letter from Joseph Benedict—dated Utica 3. Octr. 1844. claiming a pension for his father, for service of his grandfather— The papers of these three claims I took to the Pension Office, and left them with the Commissioner James L. Edwards, who promised answers to them— I met Mr Frye who has removed to the seven buildings and I returned the visit of Mr Pakenham, the Minister from Great Britain— He told me he had made very little progress with Mr Calhoun in the Negotiation for the Oregon. And he avowed the claim of Great Britain to the Columbia river— I received a Letter of 4 November current from George Joy, Pentonville, London with sundry documents printed and manuscript, and I wrote to George Rundle to enclose the certificates of Schuylkill bridge Stock.
